title: Australia news live: Ticketek says Ashes ticket sales kicked off ‘all without issue’ amid complaints from cricket fans
snippets:
Follow today’s news live

  • Anthony Albanese shrugs off Dorinda Cox’s sharp criticism of Labor before party switch

  • Get our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcast

Social housing waitlists grew by 26,000 households in six-year period

In the six years to 2022, Australia’s social housing waitlists grew by more than 26,000 households, while the number of households able to get into social housing fell by 6,400, according to new analysis from the Australian Housing and Urban Research Institute.

Australia’s social housing system needs to make stronger assurances of different kinds of housing assistance that reach beyond the constraints of unavailable social housing stock. It needs to do more for the people who are waiting, as well as for those already in social housing.

Housing legislation should enshrine the right of individuals to reasonable and necessary housing assistance, and provide for a range of forms of housing assistance that are designed in participation with recipients to better meet their needs.

Continue reading...

titles: Australia news live: Ticketek says Ashes ticket sales kicked off ‘all without issue’ amid complaints from cricket fans
Australia news live: Ticketek says Ashes ticket sales kicked off ‘all without issue’ amid complaints from cricket fans
summary: Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese dismissed criticism from Dorinda Cox before her party switch. Meanwhile, a report from the Australian Housing and Urban Research Institute revealed that social housing waitlists in Australia increased by over 26,000 households in the six years leading up to 2022, while the number of households gaining access to social housing decreased by 6,400. The report emphasizes the need for stronger housing assistance measures beyond the current social housing stock and suggests legislation to guarantee the right to adequate housing assistance.
constructiveness_reason: This story provides useful information about the social housing situation in Australia, offering insights into the increasing demand and decreasing supply. However, it doesn't provide any solutions or progress towards addressing this issue.

title: Palestinians killed after Israeli military opens fire at aid distribution point, Gaza’s civil defence agency says – Israel-Gaza war live
snippets:
IDF says it fired at ‘individual suspects who advanced towards troops’ during incident at aid point in southern Gaza Strip

  • Palestinians killed by Israeli fire at aid point, Gaza officials say

  • Israeli strikes on Gaza schools part of deliberate strategy, say sources

At least ten Palestinians have been reported killed by Israeli strikes across the Gaza Strip on Tuesday morning, according to news agency Wafa.

The dead, it reported, included two children killed in a strike on a house sheltering displaced people in Khan Younis.

Continue reading...

The incident has sparked further scrutiny of Israel's military tactics in the region.

title: NSW Coalition and unions unlikely allies against Labor’s ‘nasty laws’ to curtail workers’ compensation claims
snippets:
Opposition leader says Minns government’s bill to change threshold for psychological injuries will ‘punish the most severely injured workers’

  • Get our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcast

The New South Wales opposition and the union movement have become unlikely allies in opposing the central plank of the Minns government’s “nasty laws” to curtail workers’ compensation claims for psychological injuries.

The opposition leader, Mark Speakman, said on Tuesday he would be pushing for the status quo of 15% impairment as the level of injury that would trigger compensation. He wants amendments or a parliamentary inquiry.

Sign up for Guardian Australia’s breaking news email

Continue reading...

titles: NSW Coalition and unions unlikely allies against Labor’s ‘nasty laws’ to curtail workers’ compensation claims
NSW Coalition and unions unlikely allies against Labor’s ‘nasty laws’ to curtail workers’ compensation claims
summary: The New South Wales opposition and union movements are opposing the Minns government's proposed bill that aims to modify the compensation claims process for psychological injuries. They argue that the new legislation, which seeks to change the threshold for these claims, will adversely affect severely injured workers. Opposition leader Mark Speakman is advocating for retaining the current threshold of 15% impairment for compensation to be triggered and is calling for amendments to the bill or a parliamentary inquiry into the matter.
constructiveness_reason: This story provides useful information about the proposed changes to the compensation claims process for psychological injuries in New South Wales. It informs readers about the opposition to the bill and the potential impacts on injured workers. However, it does not report on any solutions or improvements to the issue.

title: Unveiling under-the-barrier electron dynamics in strong field tunneling
snippets: Tunneling is a peculiar quantum phenomenon with no classical counterpart. It plays an essential role for strong field phenomena in atoms and molecules interacting with intense lasers. Processes such as high-order harmonic generation are driven by electron dynamics following tunnel ionization.
titles: Unveiling under-the-barrier electron dynamics in strong field tunneling
summary: Tunneling, a unique quantum phenomenon, is crucial in strong field phenomena in atoms and molecules when they interact with intense lasers. This process underpins high-order harmonic generation, which is propelled by electron dynamics after tunnel ionization.
constructiveness_reason: This story provides some useful information about a unique quantum phenomenon, but it may not be applicable or understandable to a general audience. It doesn't highlight any solutions or progress, but it does provide some depth and insight into a specific scientific topic.

title: The world's natural history collections are ready to aid in pandemic preparedness
snippets: Across the world, natural history museums hold about 3 billion specimens of plants and animals in collections—and these collections may also contain information needed to prevent, prepare for, and respond to potential future pandemics.
titles: The world's natural history collections are ready to aid in pandemic preparedness
summary: Natural history museums globally house approximately 3 billion specimens of plants and animals. These collections are recognized for potentially holding crucial information that could aid in preventing, preparing for, and responding to future pandemics.
constructiveness_reason: This story clearly highlights how existing resources (natural history collections) can be utilized for a pressing global issue (pandemic preparedness). It provides useful insights and awareness about potential solutions and progress in this field.

title: Does Your Child Have Long COVID? Researchers Uncover Key Symptoms
snippets: Long COVID affects young children differently, with unique symptom patterns revealed in a new study. Long COVID, a condition where symptoms continue long after the initial infection, can affect people of all ages — even the youngest among us. But in infants, toddlers, and preschoolers, these lingering symptoms often look very different from what we [...]
titles: Does Your Child Have Long COVID? Researchers Uncover Key Symptoms
summary: A new study has found that Long COVID presents differently in young children, including infants, toddlers, and preschoolers, with unique symptom patterns distinct from those seen in adults. This condition involves symptoms persisting well beyond the initial COVID-19 infection.
constructiveness_reason: This story provides useful information for parents and caregivers about the symptoms of Long COVID in children. It increases awareness about this health issue, but it doesn't report on any solutions or progress in treating this condition.

title: New AI Spots Hidden Heart Attack Risk at the Click of a Button
snippets: A new AI tool can rapidly detect hidden cardiovascular and fall risks in older adults using routine bone scans by identifying arterial calcification, an often-overlooked but critical health indicator. Researchers from Edith Cowan University (ECU), in collaboration with the University of Manitoba, have developed an automated machine learning program capable of identifying potential cardiovascular events [...]
titles: New AI Spots Hidden Heart Attack Risk at the Click of a Button
summary: Researchers from Edith Cowan University and the University of Manitoba have developed a new AI tool that can quickly identify hidden risks of cardiovascular events and falls in older adults. This is achieved by detecting arterial calcification from routine bone scans, a key indicator of heart health that is commonly overlooked. This innovation allows for the rapid assessment of heart attack risk with the click of a button.
constructiveness_reason: This story is highly constructive. It informs readers about a new AI tool that can help identify hidden risks of heart attacks, contributing to their understanding of health technology. It also reports on an innovative solution to a problem, thereby highlighting progress in the medical field.

title: Doctors Have Been Saying Sugar Is Bad – But They Missed This
snippets: Think all sugar is equally bad? Think again. A massive new study reveals that the source of sugar makes all the difference. While sugary drinks like soda and even fruit juice sharply increase the risk of type 2 diabetes, sugars in solid foods—especially nutrient-rich ones—may actually be less harmful or even protective. The findings challenge [...]
titles: Doctors Have Been Saying Sugar Is Bad – But They Missed This
summary: A large study has found that the source of sugar intake affects health outcomes differently. Sugary drinks, including soda and fruit juice, significantly raise the risk of type 2 diabetes. However, sugars found in solid foods, particularly those rich in nutrients, may be less harmful or even have protective effects against the disease. This challenges previous beliefs that all sugars have equally negative health impacts.
constructiveness_reason: This story is constructive as it provides readers with actionable insights about sugar intake and its impact on health, particularly type 2 diabetes. It also increases awareness about the nuanced effects of different sources of sugar, contributing to a deeper understanding of nutrition.
